abstract:
300-word version:

Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of First Pass Effect in Mechanical Thrombectomy: ASTER Trial

Background: The first pass effect (FPE) is defined as (near-)complete revascularization after a single device pass without rescue therapy, linked to improved outcomes in acute ischemic stroke. This study assesses FPE rates and outcomes in the ASTER trial comparing stent retriever (SR) and contact aspiration (CA) techniques.

Methods: The ASTER trial was a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint trial conducted from October 2015 to October 2016. Adults with anterior circulation ischemic stroke within 6 hours of onset were randomized to SR (n=189) or CA (n=192). The primary outcome was favorable clinical outcome (mRS 0-2) at 90 days. Randomization was stratified by intravenous thrombolysis use, and angiographic outcomes were assessed by a blinded core laboratory. The analysis included 336 patients using an intention-to-treat approach.

Results: FPE was achieved in 97 of 336 patients (28.9%), with no significant difference between SR (31.3%) and CA (26.3%) (adjusted RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.54 to 1.31; p=0.44). FPE was associated with improved clinical outcomes (adjusted RR 1.38, 95% CI 1.22 to 1.56) and lower mortality (adjusted RR 0.56, 95% CI 0.35 to 0.88). FPE also resulted in fewer hemorrhagic transformations (adjusted RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.71 to 1.00) and procedural complications (adjusted RR 0.51, 95% CI 0.26 to 0.99).

Interpretation: Both SR and CA achieved similar FPE rates, with FPE linked to better outcomes and reduced complications. Further research is needed to enhance FPE rates and identify predictors.

Trial registration: NCT02523261

Funding: Not specified.
